item.title: Cover note at the faculty of science magazine
item.description: Playing as a team with same partners enable us to early acquire individual skills that would hardly be achieved by playing alone. These results allow us to rethink new teaching-learning strategies, highlights the cover of the faculty of sciences magazine.

item.title: Faculty of science computer programming workshop (with Python)
Social learning in cultural evolution contexts
item.description:
Workshop

In the workshop, tools for complex systems applied to social systems were presented. It was organized under a theoretical-practical modality and seminars of invited professors. The objective was to create a space for the encounter between the social sciences and the rest of the scientific disciplines. It was a great opportunity to exchange ideas on how to apply the tools used for complex systems to problems coming from the social area.

item.title: Evidence in favor of a scientific theory
TrueSkill, Technical Report
item.description: The first skill estimator was developed by Arpad Elo, adopted by the World Chess Federations around 1970. TrueSkill is just the bayesian multiplayer version of Elo model, published by Microsoft in 2007. In this technical report I derive, step by step, the analytical solution of the model.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Welcome to Slides

Academic

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = \;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: Artificial cultural evolution algorithm
item.description: Humans had an adaptive leap when they developed the ability to imitate, to acquire information based on the experience of others. This allowed learning and memory decentralization in a population of agents, leading to a process of cultural evolution in which valuable knowledge emerges even if it is too costly for it to be discovered by individual agents. We are working on a social reinforcement learning model, based on individual experience and social learning transmition, in order to study non-analytical properties of the cultural evolution process.

item.title: Computer Science introduction for empricial sciences (with Python)
Social learning factors in online games
item.description: We exploit the virtually infinite repository of human behavior available in Internet to study a relevant topic in anthropological science: how social learning strategies may affect human skill acquisition.

item.title: Bayesian Inference
item.description:
Beyond any debate, what is certain is that Bayesian Inference allows us to optimally update our beliefs given a model and a data set. What more could you ask for?

Handbooks

Some initial bibliography

  • Lee M.D. and Wagenmakers E.J. Bayesian Cognitive Modeling: A Practical Course
  • Richard McElreath. Statistical Rethinking: A Bayesian Course with Examples in R and Stan
  • Andrew Gelman et al. Bayesian Data Analysis
Evidence in favor of a scientific theory

In a 1935 paper and in his book Theory of Probability, Jeffreys developed a methodology for quantify the evidence in favor of a scientific theory. Bayesian model selection automatically encodes a preference for simpler, more constrained models. Many of the “machine learning” regularization techniques can be seen as an approximation to Bayesian inference.

  • Tom Minka. Evidence
  • Larry Wasserman. Bayesian Model Selection and Model Averaging
  • Robert Kass and Adrian Raftery Bayes factors and model uncertainty

Hands-on

item.title: Cultural diverisity at the colonial-modernity period
item.description: The only agents capable of developing successful solutions to complex problems are the peoples through their evolutionary history (Rita Segato, Elinor Ostrom, Robert Boyd). The advance of the colonial-modern proyect, under the figure of the Republican States and private enterprises, destroys much of the cultural diversity accumulated over thousands of years by human populations. It is therefore necessary to restore the jurisdictional and deliberative autonomy of peoples in order to guarantee the process of cultural evolution, the only means capable of solving the serious ecological and economic problems that humanity faces today.
